citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, the licensee did not have documentation of training on the contingency plan for personnel.
Employees must know their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the contingency plan in order to ensure animal care
and welfare in emergent events. The licensee must train personnel on the contingency plan and new employees must be
trained within 30 days of hire. Correct by 8 May 2023.

On 27 February 2023, a newly acquired non-flighted female Big Brown Bat (AF3798) was found outside of their primary
enclosure at morning daily observation check. She was found on the ground approximately 10 feet away from the
enclosure and was outside of the enclosure for an estimated maximum of 12 hours. The bat was checked by the keeper
and a veterinary technician same day and found to have no injuries. The next day, a veterinarian completed an intake
exam and found the bat to be healthy with no new injuries. It was discovered that the mat in the tray slot at the bottom of
the enclosure allowed a gap big enough for the bat to fit through. The gap was eliminated with additional corrugated
twinwall plastic material and the animal has since been contained. Animals that escape their enclosures may sustain
injuries. The licensee must ensure that housing facilities for animals are constructed of appropriate material for the
animal, are in good repair and that they contain the animals.

On 24 January 2023, a male Prairie Dog (AF3715) was caught for evaluation of worsening bite wounds to the face and
neck. Records indicate the wounds were observed and treatment attempted the month prior. A sedated exam on 25
January 2023 conducted by a veterinarian revealed a dull animal on capture with delayed to absent visual responses and
deep puncture wounds over the face, neck, back, shoulders and scrotum likely due to aggression from other prairie dogs
in the enclosure. Humane euthanasia was elected due to severity of injuries. A report of a necropsy performed by a
veterinary pathologist on 7 February 2023 confirms that the lacerations to the left eye, head and face are consistent with
bite wound trauma. Animals housed with other animals that interfere with their health or comfort may result in injury or
death of the animal. The licensee must ensure that animals housed in the same primary enclosure are compatible, even
when displaying seasonal behaviors. Correct from this day forward of 10 April 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.134(c) 
   
Contingency planning. 
At time of inspection, the licensee did not have documentation of training on the contingency plan for personnel. 
Employees must know their roles and responsibilities as outlined in the contingency plan in order to ensure animal care 
and welfare in emergent events. The licensee must train personnel on the contingency plan and new employees must be 
trained within 30 days of hire. Correct by 8 May 2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
On 27 February 2023, a newly acquired non-flighted female Big Brown Bat (AF3798) was found outside of their primary 
enclosure at morning daily observation check.  She was found on the ground approximately 10 feet away from the 
enclosure and was outside of the enclosure for an estimated maximum of 12 hours.  The bat was checked by the keeper 
and a veterinary technician same day and found to have no injuries.  The next day, a veterinarian completed an intake 
exam and found the bat to be healthy with no new injuries. It was discovered that the mat in the tray slot at the bottom of 
the enclosure allowed a gap big enough for the bat to fit through.  The gap was eliminated with additional corrugated 
twinwall plastic material and the animal has since been contained.  Animals that escape their enclosures may sustain

injuries.  The licensee must ensure that housing facilities for animals are constructed of appropriate material for the 
animal, are in good repair and that they contain the animals. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
On 24 January 2023, a male Prairie Dog (AF3715) was caught for evaluation of worsening bite wounds to the face and 
neck.  Records indicate the wounds were observed and treatment attempted the month prior. A sedated exam on 25 
January 2023 conducted by a veterinarian revealed a dull animal on capture with delayed to absent visual responses and 
deep puncture wounds over the face, neck, back, shoulders and scrotum likely due to aggression from other prairie dogs 
in the enclosure.  Humane euthanasia was elected due to severity of injuries.  A report of a necropsy performed by a 
veterinary pathologist on 7 February 2023 confirms that the lacerations to the left eye, head and face are consistent with 
bite wound trauma.  Animals housed with other animals that interfere with their health or comfort may result in injury or 
death of the animal. The licensee must ensure that animals housed in the same primary enclosure are compatible, even 
when displaying seasonal behaviors.  Correct from this day forward of 10 April 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
